awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Extending Inquiry-Oriented Linear Algebra
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by improving student learning in linear algebra.  To accomplish this goal, the project will create research-based teaching and instructor support materials for linear algebra. This project is a collaboration between Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Florida State University, Arizona State University, and Clayton State University.  It aligns with national calls to engage students in learning through inquiry.  To this end, it intends to help students learn mathematics by engaging in mathematical discussions, developing and testing conjectures, and explaining and justifying their thinking.  The project has four main goals: (i) create  four new units that integrate with and complement existing Inquiry-Oriented Linear Algebra materials; (ii) create instructional support materials for the four new units; (iii) contribute new knowledge through empirical research about student reasoning and effective inquiry-oriented instructional practices in linear algebra; and (iv) foster inquiry-oriented instructional practices in undergraduate mathematics. The two broad research questions for the project are: (i) What mathematical conceptions do students develop through their engagement with the tasks? (ii) What instructional moves facilitate student learning in this setting?  The project has the potential to advance knowledge about and capacity for using inquiry-oriented approaches to improve undergraduate instruction in mathematics, particularly linear algebra.

To accomplish its goals, the project will use a Design Research Cycle comprised of phases of Task Design, Paired Teaching Experiments (Steffe & Thompson, 2000), Classroom Teaching Experiments (Cobb, 2000), Online Working Groups (Fortune, Keene, & Hall, 2017), and Website Development. The project will extend the current Inquiry-Oriented Linear Algebra materials to include an entire introductory linear algebra course, providing a comprehensive set of supports to help instructors adopt an inquiry-oriented approach to teaching linear algebra. By focusing on new instructors and settings, the project has the potential to extend the impact of active learning and inquiry-oriented teaching to a larger number of students and institutions. Data to address the research questions will be collected from at least twelve institutions that vary in geographic location, institution type, size, and  student demographics, thus enriching the diversity of the research population. Resources developed by the project and its research results will be disseminated through websites, workshops, and publications in both research and practitioner journals within mathematics and mathematics education. In addition, the project's consideration of and adherence to research recommendations regarding equity and access will promote and advance inquiry-oriented, equitable teaching practices. This work has the potential to benefit society by improving undergraduate mathematics instruction and extending the use of inquiry-oriented teaching. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.  Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Extending Inquiry-Oriented Linear Algebra (IOLA-X) project has served the national interest by developing research-based instructional sequences for several core topics in introductory undergraduate linear algebra. The project advanced both the field's knowledge and capacity for improving undergraduate STEM instruction in content-specific ways as well as more generalizable ways. Beyond the importance of this content for STEM disciplines, our research in the teaching and learning of linear algebra contributed to the limited knowledge base for how students learn many concepts. The project team's expertise in linear algebra education research, curriculum development, and instructional change made us well-qualified to conduct this research. This project was a collaboration between Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Florida State University, Arizona State University, and Clayton State University. The project aligned with national calls to engage students in learning through inquiry, helping students learn mathematics by engaging in mathematical discussions, developing and testing conjectures, and explaining and justifying their thinking. We focused our work on both the practical and theoretical by creating new curricula in tandem with new research knowledge about the teaching and learning of linear algebra.

The goals of the project were to:

(1) create four new units that integrate with and complement existing Inquiry-Oriented Linear Algebra materials;

(2) create instructional support materials for the four new units;

(3) contribute new knowledge through empirical research about student reasoning and effective inquiry-oriented instructional practices in linear algebra; and

(4) foster inquiry-oriented instructional practices in undergraduate mathematics.

The major accomplishment of this project was the development of four new units of instructional tasks and support materials. The project extended the existing Inquiry-Oriented Linear Algebra materials spanning an introductory linear algebra course, providing a detailed set of supports to help instructors adopt an inquiry-oriented approach to teaching linear algebra. The new units -- focused on solution sets to linear systems, determinants, subspaces, and least squares -- complement the previously developed units, which focused on span and linear independence, matrices as linear transformations, and diagonalization. All of the materials are freely accessible on the website: https://iola.math.vt.edu (registration is required for access to instructor support materials).

The two broad research questions for the project were: (i) What mathematical conceptions do students develop through their engagement with the tasks? (ii) What instructional moves facilitate student learning in this setting? The project has advanced knowledge about and capacity for using inquiry-oriented approaches to improve undergraduate mathematics instruction, particularly in linear algebra.

To accomplish its goals, the project used a Design Research Cycle (Wawro et al., 2022) comprised of phases of Task Design, Paired Teaching Experiments (Steffe & Thompson, 2000), Classroom Teaching Experiments (Cobb, 2000), Online Working Groups (Fortune, Keene, & Hall, 2017), and Website Development. By focusing on new instructors and settings, the project extended the impact of active learning and inquiry-oriented teaching to a more significant number of students,institutions, and institutional settings. It also directly developed the expertise of the undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral team members involved in the project’s work.

The research team for this project included 4 faculty (who led the design and research process and oversaw all aspects of project work), 11 graduate students (several of these project members completed their doctorates and continued working with the project in their post-doctoral work), and 3 undergraduate students. We are grateful to have partnered with 14 instructors at a range of institutions across the U.S., who piloted our materials and provided feedback that helped us refine our instructional materials for publication on our project website. In addition to developing the four instructional units, our team published four manuscripts in peer-reviewed outlets (journals and book chapters), published over thirty national and international conference proceedings, and gave over four dozen presentations (talks or posters)at conferences, colloquia, seminars or workshops to disseminate results from this project.

This work has benefited society by improving undergraduate mathematics instruction and extending the field’s understanding and use of inquiry-oriented teaching. Many scholars who have been supported by this grant have continued their work in directions that extend beyond the original scope of this grant. We believe these ongoing efforts to be evidence of the support and development this project provided the industrious early-career scholars who were supported as part of the IOLA-X project.
